summary: In this context, Buta-1,3-diene and Polycyclic Hydrocarbons (PAHs) are both identified as carcinogenic compounds found in fumes generated during high-temperature cooking. The study highlights the presence of various toxicants, including Buta-1,3-diene and PAHs, in cooking emissions, linking them to increased lung cancer risk. Both compounds are classified as harmful, with specific references to their carcinogenic potential by the IARC, indicating a significant relationship in terms of health risks associated with cooking methods.
